properties.name: Veguitas 1119
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   U-2 Shootdown Cubans look at the wreckage of the U-2 piloted by Major Rudolf Anderson shot down over the village of Veguitas at 11:19 EDT on October 27, 1962, at the height of the Cuban missile crisis. Anderson's plane was hit by two missiles fired from the nearby SAM site at Los Angelos. The pilot's body was later returned to the United States for burial.

properties.name: McCoy AFB
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   U-2 Shootdown Major Rudolf Anderson took off in a U-2 from McCoy AFB at 09:09 EDT on October 27, 1962, at the height of the Cuban missile crisis. He was shot down over the village of Veguitas in eastern Cuba by a Soviet SAM missile. Follow his flight on this map.

properties.name: Los Angelos SAM site
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   U-2 shootdown On October 27, 1962, at the height of the Cuban missile crisis, missiles fired from this SAM site brought down an American U-2 piloted by Maj. Rudolf Anderson. A U.S. Air Force Reconnaissance plane had flown over the site the previous day, and taken photographs of the site, with the launchers in their firing positions. Radar vans can be observed at the center of the site.

properties.name: Havana East SAM
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Soviet SAM sites Soviet Air Defenses were activated shortly after midnight on October 27, 1962 at the height of the Soviet missile crisis. An American spy ship, the USS Oxford, detected emissions from Havana East and two other SAM sites, after the Soviets switched on the tracking radar known as Spoon Rest. The outlines of the Havana East site are still visible on Google Earth. Click overlay for a 1962 photograph.

properties.name: USS Oxford October 27
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Soviet SAM sites Soviet Air Defenses were activated shortly after midnight on October 27, 1962 at the height of the Cuban missile crisis. An American spy ship, the USS Oxford, detected emissions from Mariel, Havana, and Matanzas SAM sites, after the Soviets switched on the tracking radar known as Spoon Rest.

properties.name: Filipinas
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Targeting Guantanamo During the night of October 26-27, a Soviet nuclear cruise missile unit moved to a pre-prepared site near the village of Filipinas, just 15 miles from the U.S. Naval Base at Guantanamo. As the Soviet convoy approached the site at dawn, the Cuban defenders opened fire because of a mixup over passwords. The cruise missiles were under the command of a major, and lacked any special locks or codes to prevent them from being fired at the U.S. naval base.

properties.name: Guantanamo Naval Base
properties.description: ONE MINUTE TO MIDNIGHT by Michael Dobbs The definitive account of the Cuban missile crisis "A tour de force, a dramatic, nail-biting page-turner that is also an important work of scholarship".--Martin Sherwin. "First rate great history and a great read."--Ray Garthoff. “Dobbs’s hour-to-hour chronology of those tormenting days when the world stood on the verge of nuclear holocaust is riveting." --Dino Brugioni. Buy on Amazon   Defending Guantanamo U.S. Marines on guard at Guantanamo Naval Base during the October 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis. The marines were unaware that Soviet troops were deployed only 15 miles away, armed with nuclear cruise missiles, that could have destroyed the naval base in a few minutes. Each FKR cruise missile was armed with a 14-kiloton nuclear warhead, roughly the size of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima.
